src/include/sysdefines.h

Go to the documentation of this file.
00001 /*! \file sysdefines.h
00002  *  This file defines constants and data types used by system calls.
00003  *
00004  */ 
00005  
00006 #ifndef _SYSDEFINES_H_
00007 #define _SYSDEFINES_H_ 
00008 
00009 /* Constant declarations. */
00010 
00011 /*! Return code when system call returns normally. */
00012 #define ALL_OK                  (0)
00013 /*! Return code when system call returns with an error. */
00014 #define ERROR                   (-1)
00015 /*! Return code when system call is unknown. */
00016 #define ERROR_ILLEGAL_SYSCALL   (-2)
00017 /*! Return code when a message is too long. */
00018 #define ERROR_MESSAGE_TOO_LONG  (-3)
00019 /*! Max number of columns in VGA buffer. */
00020 #define MAX_COLS                (80)
00021 /*! Max number of columns in VGA buffer. */
00022 #define MAX_ROWS                (25)
00023 
00024 /*! System call that returns the version of the kernel. */
00025 #define SYSCALL_VERSION         (0)
00026 /*! System call that prints a string. */
00027 #define SYSCALL_PRINTS          (1)
00028 /*! System call that prints a hexadecimal value. */
00029 #define SYSCALL_PRINTHEX        (2)
00030 /*! System call that pauses execution by invoking the bochs debugger. */
00031 #define SYSCALL_DEBUGGER        (3) 
00032 
00033 
00034 /*! System call that terminates the currently running
00035  *  thread. It takes no parameters. Terminates the process
00036  *  when there are no threads left. */
00037 #define SYSCALL_TERMINATE       (4)
00038 
00039 /*! System call that creates a new process with one single
00040  *  thread. It takes an index into the executable table in
00041  *  rdi. The program used is the executable whose index is
00042  *  passed in rdi. */
00043 #define SYSCALL_CREATEPROCESS   (5)
00044 
00045 /*! System call that blocks the calling thread a number of clocks ticks. The
00046    number of clock ticks is passed in rdi. There are 200 clock
00047    ticks per second.*/
00048 #define SYSCALL_PAUSE         (6)
00049 
00050 /*! System call that returns the current system time. The system time is the 
00051     number of clock ticks since system start. There are 200 clock ticks per 
00052     second. */
00053 #define SYSCALL_TIME            (7)
00054 
00055 /*! System call that allocates a memory block. The length of the requested 
00056     memory block is passed in rdi. Allocation flags for the block is passed 
00057     in rsi. The system call returns the address or an error code. */
00058 #define SYSCALL_ALLOCATE        (8)
00059 
00060 /*! The allocated block is to be readonly. */
00061 #define ALLOCATE_FLAG_READONLY  (1)
00062 
00063 /*! The allocated block can contain executable instructions. */
00064 #define ALLOCATE_FLAG_EX        (2)
00065 
00066 /*! System call that frees a memory block allocated through the allocate 
00067     system call. The address of the memory block is passed in rdi. The 
00068     system call returns  ALL_OK if successful or an error code if 
00069     unsuccessful. */
00070 #define SYSCALL_FREE            (9)
00071 
00072 /*! System call that allocates a port. The identity number of the port is 
00073     passed in rdi. The system call returns a handle to the port or an error 
00074     code if unsuccessful. 
00075  */
00076 #define SYSCALL_ALLOCATEPORT    (10)
00077 
00078 /*! System call that finds a port. The identity number of the port is passed 
00079     in rdi. The owning process identity is passed in rsi. The system call 
00080     returns a handle to the port or an error code if unsuccessful. 
00081  */
00082 #define SYSCALL_FINDPORT        (11)
00083 
00084 /*! System call that sends a message. The handle of the destination port is 
00085     passed in rdi. The message type is passed in rsi. A pointer to the 
00086     message is passed in rbx. The system call returns ALL_OK if successful 
00087     or an error code if unsuccessful. 
00088    
00089     There are three defined message types: short messages, long messages and 
00090     notifications. Short messages are passed in registers. Notifications are 
00091     single bit messages that will never block. Long messages are partially 
00092     located in memory.
00093 
00094     NOTE: You only need to implement short messages functionality in task 5B.
00095     Notification and long messages functionality is implemented in task 5A. 
00096     The functionality to be implemented in task 5A has a slightly different
00097     interface. This interface is described in the instructions.
00098    */
00099 #define SYSCALL_SEND            (12)
00100 #define SYSCALL_MSG_SHORT        (0)
00101 #define SYSCALL_MSG_LONG         (1)
00102 #define SYSCALL_MSG_NOTIFICATION (2)
00103 
00104 /*! System call that receives a message. The handle of the port on which to 
00105     receive is passed in rdi. 1 is passed in register rsi if long messages 
00106     are permitted. Register rbx holds a pointer to a buffer that will hold
00107     the received message.
00108 
00109     The system call returns ALL_OK if successful or an error code if 
00110     unsuccessful. Register rsi holds the received message type. 
00111     Register rdi holds the identity of process from which the message was 
00112     received.
00113 
00114     NOTE: You only need to implement short messages functionality in task 5B.
00115     Notification and long messages functionality is implemented in task 5A. 
00116     The functionality to be implemented in task 5A has a slightly different
00117     interface. This interface is described in the instructions.
00118    */
00119 #define SYSCALL_RECEIVE         (14)
00120 
00121 /*! Returns the process identity of the calling thread in rax. */
00122 #define SYSCALL_GETPID          (15)
00123 
00124 /*! Creates a new thread in the process of the calling thread. The value of 
00125     rip register of the new thread is passed in the rdi registe. The value of 
00126     the rsp register of the new thread is passed in rsi. rflags of the new 
00127     thread is set to 0x200. The other registers are undefinied.
00128 
00129     The system call returns in rax ALL_OK if successful or an error code if 
00130     unsuccessful.
00131    */
00132 #define SYSCALL_CREATETHREAD    (16)
00133 
00134 /*! Creates a new semaphore and returns if successful the handle of the
00135     semaphore in the rax register. The initial value of the semaphore count
00136     value is passed in the rdi register.
00137    
00138     If unsuccessful the system call returns an error code in rax. */
00139 #define SYSCALL_CREATESEMAPHORE (17)
00140 
00141 /*! Performs a semaphore down operation. The handle of the semaphore is passed
00142     in the rdi register.
00143 
00144     The system call returns in rax ALL_OK if successful or an error code if 
00145     unsuccessful.
00146    */
00147 #define SYSCALL_SEMAPHOREDOWN   (18)
00148 
00149 /*! Performs an semaphore up operation. The handle of the semaphore is passed
00150     in the rdi register.
00151 
00152     The system call returns in rax ALL_OK if successful or an error code if 
00153     unsuccessful.
00154    */
00155 #define SYSCALL_SEMAPHOREUP     (19)
00156 
00157 /*! Creates a new mutex and returns if successful the handle of the mutex in 
00158     the rax register. If unsuccessful the system call returns  an error code 
00159     in rax. */
00160 #define SYSCALL_CREATEMUTEX     (20)
00161 
00162 /*! Creates a new condition variable and returns if successful the handle of 
00163     the condition variable in the rax register. If unsuccessful the system 
00164     call returns  an error code in rax. */
00165 #define SYSCALL_CREATECONDITIONVARIABLE (21)
00166 
00167 /*! Performs a mutex lock operation. The handle of the mutex is passed
00168     in the rdi register.
00169 
00170     The system call returns in rax ALL_OK if successful or an error code if 
00171     unsuccessful.
00172    */
00173 #define SYSCALL_MUTEXLOCK       (22)
00174 
00175 /*! Performs a mutex unlock operation. The handle of the mutex is passed
00176     in the rdi register.
00177 
00178     The system call returns in rax ALL_OK if successful or an error code if 
00179     unsuccessful.
00180    */
00181 #define SYSCALL_MUTEXUNLOCK     (23)
00182 
00183 /*! Performs a wait operation on a condition variable. The handle of the 
00184     condition variable is passed in the rdi register. The handle of the 
00185     associated mutex is passed in the rsi register.
00186 
00187     The system call returns in rax ALL_OK if successful or an error code if 
00188     unsuccessful.
00189    */
00190 #define SYSCALL_CONDITIONVARIABLEWAIT (24)
00191 
00192 /*! Performs a signal operation on a condition variable. The handle of the 
00193     condition variable is passed in the rdi register.
00194 
00195     The system call returns in rax ALL_OK if successful or an error code if 
00196     unsuccessful.
00197    */
00198 #define SYSCALL_CONDITIONVARIABLESIGNAL (25)
00199 
00200 /*! Prints a string at a specific place on the screen. The pointer to the
00201     string, i.e., the address of the first byte of the string is passed
00202     in register rdx. The position on the screen is defined with a row and
00203     column pair. The column is passed in register rsi and the row is
00204     passed in register rdi.
00205 
00206     The system call returns ALL_OK in rax if successful or an error code if
00207     unsuccessful.
00208    */
00209 #define SYSCALL_PRINTAT         (26)
00210 
00211 /*! Returns the next scan code from the keyboard in the rax register. The
00212     system call blocks until data is available.
00213 
00214     The system call returns a keyboard scan code in rax if successful or an 
00215     error code if unsuccessful.
00216  */
00217 #define SYSCALL_GETSCANCODE     (27)
00218

00220 /* Type declarations. */
00221 
00222 /*! Describes a message. */
00223 struct message
00224 {
00225  unsigned long quad_0;
00226  unsigned long quad_1;
00227  unsigned long quad_2;
00228  unsigned long quad_3;
00229  unsigned long quad_4;
00230  unsigned long quad_5;
00231  unsigned long quad_6;
00232  unsigned long quad_7;
00233 };
00234 
00235 #endif
